physDesc.p: This description is abbreviated from Daniela Mairhofer, Medieval Manuscripts from the Mainz Charterhouse in the Bodleian Library, Oxford: A Descriptive Catalogue (Oxford, 2018), pp. 319–334. For purposes of scholarly citation, reference to the printed catalogue is requested.

supportDesc.foliation: i-iii, 1-207 (no. 96 trebled: the paper bifolium 96b & 96c foliated in a different hand, which also changed the original fol. 96 to 96a; the endleaves in a different (20th-cent.) hand, the penultimate leaf ignored, the numbering of the last two folios corrected by the cataloguer.)

binding.p: Brown tanned calf over laminated pulpboard for Abp. Laud, 1637–1639.

history.provenance: A book consisting of four parts, all of which were, to judge from script, parchment and style, produced in France; parts A & B, which share quire signatures, were presumably consolidated with parts C & D only in the course of the Laudian binding.
William Laud, 1573–1645: his ex-libris inscription, dated 1638, at the lower margin of fol. 1r.
history.acquisition: Given to the Bodleian as part of his third donation, dispatched on 28 June 1639.

msItem.author: Ps.-Stephen Langton
msItem.title: Summa theologiae siue Liber quaestionum theologiae
msItem.rubric: Liber questionum theologie. hic tractat primo de Diuina essencia et de tribus personis. Deinde de angelis et sic de aliis.
msItem.incipit: Breues dies hominis sunt. et numerus mensium eius infra primos limites cohartatur. Proinde breuibus dictis est promouenda imbecillitas paruulorum
msItem.note: Unclear where the text ends. Msc. Patr. 136 of the Staatsbibliothek Bamberg preserves on fols. 1r–98v a long Summa, composed between 1202 and 1206, which has been named after its initial words Breves sunt dies hominis. The text, to be associated with the School of Poirrée, has been erroneously ascribed to Stephen Langton. MS. Laud Misc. 80 (D) preserves a more reliable copy of the Summa than the Bamberg text, but is only fragmentary. The Summa is also preserved in MSS Cambrai, BM, Ms. 402, fols. 98r–117r (complete), Paris, BnF, Lat. 3237, fols. 89r–96r, and El Escorial, Real Biblioteca del Monasterio de San Lorenzo, G.IV.14 (both fragmentary).
